502.text: Okay thanks! If you ever want to sign up for parenting messages, type "start_message". We are here to help!

521.text: Hello! We love our children and teenagers, but stress from caregiving, money, and COVID-19 can make us angry. Here is how we can maintain control and keep calm.

549.text: Stop the river at the source. The same things usually make us get stressed and angry every time. What makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?

580.text: Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.

614.text: Here are some things that can help make it less likely that bad things happen when you are angry:

634.text: Type "Y" if you want to learn more or "N" to stop this tip.

686.text: 1. Cut back on drinking alcohol or donâ€™t drink, especially when the kids are awake.

701.text: 2. Do you have weapons or things  that can be used to hurt others?  Lock them up, hide them or take them out of the home.

729.text: 3. Itâ€™s ok to have your children stay somewhere safe or take them to a place where they can get help.

750.text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Learning how to manage your anger can help you  avoid some difficult situations.

1008.text: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet during COVID-19. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. How we understand and talk about money is important. We can also learn about how we can save in ways that will benefit the family.

1057.text: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet during COVID-19. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. How we understand and talk about money with our children is important. Our children can also help us to spend and save that will benefit the family.

1130.text: Making a budget with your children and teens.

1138.text: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget together helps children understand that we all need to make hard decisions in difficult times. It can also help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.

1196.text: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget can help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.

1304.text: Step 1: What do we spend on now?

1312.text: â€¢ Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.

1328.text: â€¢ Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.

1345.text: â€¢ Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.

1356.text: â€¢ Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

1616.text: Step 4: Find out where you can get extra help

1626.text: Your government or community groups may be giving money, or food parcels to families during COVID-19. Ask about whether places in your community are giving support.

1652.text: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Millions of families find that learning ways to manage money as a family reduces family arguments and brings everyone together. That's real success!

1704.text: Our children and teens are now spending a lot more time online. Being connected helps them reduce the impact of COVID-19 and encourages them to continue with their livesâ€¦but it also presents risks and dangers.

1760.text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need any support with your children. Chat to you later!

1781.text: Here are 6 tips that can help you keep your children safe online:

1794.text: 1. Learn about the risks and dangers

1805.text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits

1812.text: 4. Spend time with your child online

1828.text: To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.

1848.text: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1855.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

1864.text: â€¢ Adults targeting children for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.

1878.text: â€¢ Harmful content â€“ like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography

1894.text: â€¢ Teens sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos of themselves.

1906.text: â€¢ Cyberbullying from other young people and strangers.

1914.text: 2. Tech fixes to protect your children online:

1922.text: â€¢ Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.

1940.text: â€¢ Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.

1953.text: â€¢ Cover webcams when not in use.

1960.text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits:

1967.text: Involve your teen in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.

1979.text: Create device-free spaces and times in your house

1996.text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits:

2003.text: Involve your child in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.

2015.text: Create device-free spaces and times in your house

2032.text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits:

2039.text: Involve your child or teen in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.

2053.text: Create device-free spaces and times in your house

2074.text: This does not mean we should ban our children from spending time online. It just means that we need to learn how to protect them in a new world.

2103.text: Help your child learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers â€“ some people are not who they say they are!

2126.text: Remind your children that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).

2139.text: Actively supervise childrenâ€™s time online, including computers, smartphones, and tablets.

2150.text: 4. Spend time with your child or teen online

2159.text: Get to know how your child experiences the digital world.

2169.text: Explore websites, social media, games, and apps together.

2177.text: Talk to your teen on how to report things that aren't OK.

2189.text: Common Sense Media has great advice for apps, games and entertainment for different ages.

2204.text: 5. Build open communication and trusting relationships

2211.text: Tell your children that if they experience something online (or anywhere) that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable, or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.

2249.text: INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals and the Child Helpline in your country to get support if you or your children experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.

2288.text: Do you want to go back and learn about another way to protect your child online?

2640.text: â€¢ Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.

2658.text: â€¢ Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.

2671.text: â€¢ Cover webcams when not in use.

2678.text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits:

2685.text: You can also create healthy and safe online habits like creating device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).

2711.text: Keep personal information private, especially from strangers. â€“ some people are not who they say they are!

2728.text: Remember that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).

2739.text: Do you want to go back and learn about another way to protect yourself online?
